title: Did Kurt Cobain hate his fans? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. Well… yes. Sort of. It’s hard to quantify. Kurt Cobain rather famously struggled with the mainstream success his band Nirvana achieved after releasing Nevermind in 1991. He had fully embraced his bands earlier identity as part of the ‘alternative’ movement and clearly seemed to feel a sense of belonging to that particular musical sub-culture. However Cobain’s songwriting instincts were more commercial and more “pop” than most alternative acts and as such he crafted an album full of ear worming hooks and melodies that rapidly grew his audience. Cobain’s response to this was a mix of gratitude that the band could now earn a good living from music and a sense of unease that his audience was no longer the ‘alternative’ crowd but was infact the same music fans who would attend Guns n’Roses and Bon Jovi shows. Cobain's discomfort was more to do with his own perception of himself and his band and how they had positioned themselves as something “different” from the mainstream rock bands who were played on the radio in those days. In particular Cobain was troubled by having his audiences filled with people who didn’t share his values. Cobain even put this sense of unease into his lyrics. He's the one Who like all our pretty songs And he likes to sing along And he likes to shoot his gun But he don't know what it means Don't know what it means (In Bloom - 1991) And his album notes: At this point I have a request for our fans. If any of you in any way hate homosexuals, people of different color, or women, please do this one favor for us - leave us the fuck alone! Don't come to our shows and don't buy our records. Incesticide Album Notes I have heard that in the latter part of his all too brief career Cobain eased up and realised that if he had this large audience then he could educate them about what he believed and quite possibly he used that idea to rationalise and justify his career to himself. Nirvana’s forth album ‘In Utero’ (1993) was written and recorded to be very different from Nevermind in an attempt to shrink the bands audience back to something Cobain was more comfortable with. However again Cobain’s pop instincts won out and it is claimed that he had the album remixed and remastered before release in order to make it more radio friendly. In the end Cobain’s attitude towards his audience was merely a symptom of the mental health issues which would eventually claim his life in early 1994. Even his suicide note refereed to how he was “faking it onstage” and how unfair that was on his audience. Sadly the only person who really cared about those issues was himself.

I scored a press pass because my best friend wrote for the Collegian at K-State. I asked Curt what currently popular band he hated the most and he said he absolutely couldn’t stand the Red Hot Chili Peppers. He seemed to like his fans just fine though…..
